text: Code

Initial Setup

Push your repository to GitHub
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/Linguistic_Data_Analysis_I.git
git push -u origin main
Enable GitHub Pages

Go to your repository on GitHub
Click Settings (top menu)
Scroll down to Pages (left sidebar)
Under Source, select:

Deploy from a branch
Branch: main (or master)
Folder: /docs

Click Save

Wait for deployment

Takes 2-10 minutes initially
Check Actions tab for progress
Green checkmark = deployed

Access your site

URL: https://YOUR_USERNAME.github.io/Linguistic_Data_Analysis_I/
Add this URL to your repo’s About section

How the Hybrid System Works
graph TD
    A[Edit .md/.qmd files] --> B{Choose workflow}
    B -->|Option 1| C[Run 'quarto render' locally]
    B -->|Option 2| D[Just commit source files]
    
    C --> E[Commit source + docs/]
    D --> F[GitHub Actions detects change]
    
    E --> G[Push to GitHub]
    F --> H[Actions runs 'quarto render']
    
    H --> I[Actions commits docs/]
    G --> J[GitHub Pages serves from docs/]
    I --> J
    
    style C fill:#90EE90
    style D fill:#FFE4B5

Verify Everything Works

Check GitHub Actions

Go to Actions tab
You should see workflows:

“Auto-Render Quarto Site”
“Verify and Update Site”

Green = working

Test the fallback
# Make a small edit
echo "\n\nTest edit" >> resources/tools/index.md

# Commit WITHOUT rendering
git add resources/tools/index.md
git commit -m "Test GitHub Actions rendering"
git push

# Watch Actions tab - should auto-render!
Check the site

Visit your GitHub Pages URL
Should see your content
Updates within minutes of pushing

Customization

Update URLs in _quarto.yml
website:
  site-url: "https://YOUR_USERNAME.github.io/Linguistic_Data_Analysis_I/"
  repo-url: "https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/Linguistic_Data_Analysis_I"


Update navbar GitHub link
navbar:
  right:
    - icon: github
      href: "https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/Linguistic_Data_Analysis_I"

Troubleshooting
Site not appearing? - Check Settings → Pages → Source is set correctly - Verify docs/ folder exists and has index.html - Check Actions tab for errors - Wait 10 minutes (first deploy is slow)
Actions failing? - Check Actions tab → Click failed workflow → View logs - Common issues: - Syntax error in .qmd file - Missing file reference - YAML formatting error
Changes not showing? - Hard refresh browser (Ctrl+Shift+R) - Check if docs/ was updated - Verify GitHub Pages deployed (green checkmark) - Clear browser cache

Tips

Render locally for big changes
Use Actions for quick fixes
Watch the Actions tab to ensure builds succeed
Tag releases for each semester:
git tag -a v2025-summer -m "Summer 2025 version"
git push origin v2025-summer
Code

How It Works

1. Primary: Local Pre-rendering

Run quarto render locally
Commit both source files and docs/ folder
Push to GitHub
Site is immediately updated



2. Fallback: GitHub Actions

Monitors all source file changes
Automatically re-renders if you forget
Ensures docs/ stays in sync with source
Adds commit with updated files

Workflows

Quick Edit Workflow
# Edit your content
edit sessions/day1/index.md

# Render locally (recommended)
quarto render

# Commit everything
git add .
git commit -m "Update day 1 content"
git push


Lazy Workflow (Let GitHub Do It)
# Edit your content
edit sessions/day1/index.md

# Just commit source (GitHub will render)
git add sessions/day1/index.md
git commit -m "Update day 1 content"
git push

# GitHub Actions will:
# 1. Detect the change
# 2. Run quarto render
# 3. Commit updated docs/


Force Rebuild
# Via GitHub UI: Actions → Verify and Update Site → Run workflow → Force render ✓

# Or trigger with empty commit
git commit --allow-empty -m "Trigger rebuild"
git push

Benefits

Fast Updates: Pre-render locally for immediate deployment
Safety Net: GitHub Actions catches forgotten renders
Consistency: Ensures docs/ always matches source
Flexibility: Work locally or through GitHub web editor
Verification: PRs show what needs rendering

Configuration

For Heavy Computations
Add to frontmatter of computation-heavy files:
---
title: "Heavy Analysis"
execute:
  freeze: true  # Cache results
---


Skip Auto-render
Add [skip ci] to commit message:
git commit -m "WIP: Draft content [skip ci]"

Monitoring
Check render status: 1. Go to Actions tab in GitHub 2. Look for ✓ or ✗ next to commits 3. Click for details if failed

Troubleshooting
If GitHub Actions fails: 1. Check the error in Actions tab 2. Fix the issue locally 3. Run quarto render locally 4. Commit and push both source and docs/
If docs/ gets out of sync: 1. Delete local docs/ folder 2. Run quarto render 3. Commit fresh docs/ folder 4. Push with message “Rebuild docs folder”

Best Practices

Usually: Render locally before pushing
Quick fixes: Let GitHub handle small edits
Heavy computation: Always pre-render locally
Check Actions: Monitor for failures
Keep synced: Don’t edit docs/ directly

Advantages

Limitations

title: Python Setup Guide
text:
Python Basics for Corpus Analysis

Text Processing Essentials

Reading Files
# Read single file
with open('filename.txt', 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
    text = f.read()

# Read multiple files
import glob
files = glob.glob('*.txt')
texts = []
for file in files:
    with open(file, 'r', encoding='utf-8') as f:
        texts.append(f.read())


Basic Text Operations
# Tokenization
words = text.split()

# Lowercase conversion
words_lower = [word.lower() for word in words]

# Remove punctuation
import string
words_clean = [word.translate(str.maketrans('', '', string.punctuation)) 
               for word in words]


Frequency Analysis
from collections import Counter

# Word frequency
word_freq = Counter(words_lower)
print(word_freq.most_common(20))

# N-gram extraction
from nltk import ngrams
bigrams = list(ngrams(words, 2))
bigram_freq = Counter(bigrams)

Runtime disconnected - Save your work frequently - Use Runtime → Reconnect - Check internet connection
Out of memory - Clear unnecessary variables: del variable_name - Restart runtime: Runtime → Restart runtime - Process data in chunks
Import errors - Install missing packages: !pip install package_name - Check package name spelling - Restart runtime after installation
File not found - Verify Google Drive is mounted - Check file path - Ensure file exists in Drive

title: Python Setup Guide
text:
Useful Code Snippets

Concordance Function
def concordance(text, word, window=30):
    """Simple KWIC concordance"""
    word_lower = word.lower()
    text_lower = text.lower()
    
    results = []
    index = 0
    while True:
        index = text_lower.find(word_lower, index)
        if index == -1:
            break
        start = max(0, index - window)
        end = min(len(text), index + len(word) + window)
        
        left = text[start:index]
        node = text[index:index + len(word)]
        right = text[index + len(word):end]
        
        results.append((left, node, right))
        index += 1
    
    return results


Collocation Finder
def find_collocations(text, target_word, window=5):
    """Find collocates within window"""
    words = text.lower().split()
    target_lower = target_word.lower()
    collocates = []
    
    for i, word in enumerate(words):
        if word == target_lower:
            start = max(0, i - window)
            end = min(len(words), i + window + 1)
            context = words[start:i] + words[i+1:end]
            collocates.extend(context)
    
    return Counter(collocates)

title: BYU Corpora Guide
text: The BYU (Brigham Young University) corpora, created by Mark Davies, provide web-based interfaces to some of the largest and most widely-used corpora in the world. These include COCA (Corpus of Contemporary American English), BNC (British National Corpus), and many others.

title: BYU Corpora Guide
text: The BYU (Brigham Young University) corpora, created by Mark Davies, provide web-based interfaces to some of the largest and most widely-used corpora in the world. These include COCA (Corpus of Contemporary American English), BNC (British National Corpus), and many others.

title: BYU Corpora Guide
text:
Available Corpora

Major English Corpora

COCA (Corpus of Contemporary American English): 1 billion words, 1990-2019
BNC (British National Corpus): 100 million words
GloWbE (Global Web-Based English): 1.9 billion words
NOW (News on the Web): 14+ billion words, updated daily
COHA (Corpus of Historical American English): 400 million words, 1810-2009



Specialized Corpora

SOAP (Corpus of American Soap Operas): 100 million words
TIME (TIME Magazine Corpus): 100 million words, 1920s-2000s
Wikipedia Corpus: 1.9 billion words

title: BYU Corpora Guide
text:
Registration and Access

Free Access

Visit english-corpora.org
Click on desired corpus
Register for free account
Limited to 20 queries per day



Academic License

Extended query limits
Download capabilities
Available through institution

title: BYU Corpora Guide
text:
Basic Interface Navigation

Search Types

List: Find all forms of a word
Chart: See frequency over time
Collocates: Find co-occurring words
Compare: Compare two corpora
KWIC: Keywords in context



Query Syntax

Basic Searches

Single word: corpus
Phrase: "corpus linguistics"
Wildcard: analyz* (analyze, analyzed, analyzing)



Advanced Searches

Part of speech: [run].[v*] (run as verb)
Lemma: [run] (all forms of run)
Synonyms: [=beautiful]

title: AntConc Guide
text: AntConc is a freeware corpus analysis toolkit for concordancing and text analysis developed by Laurence Anthony. It’s the primary tool we’ll use throughout this course for analyzing corpora.

title: AntConc Guide
text: AntConc is a freeware corpus analysis toolkit for concordancing and text analysis developed by Laurence Anthony. It’s the primary tool we’ll use throughout this course for analyzing corpora.

title: AntConc Guide
text:
System Requirements

Operating System: Windows, macOS, or Linux
Memory: 512MB RAM minimum (2GB+ recommended for large corpora)
Storage: 50MB for software installation
Display: 1024x768 resolution minimum

Windows

Download the Windows installer (.exe file)

Follow installation prompts



macOS

Download the macOS package (.dmg file)
Open the .dmg file
Drag AntConc to Applications folder



Linux

Visit AntConc website
Download the Linux version (.tar.gz)
Extract and run from terminal

Analyze formulaic language



4. Collocates

Find words that co-occur
Set span size
Calculate statistical measures

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course Title: Linguistic Data Analysis I
Credits: 2
Format: Intensive 5-day course
Language: English
Prerequisites: Graduate standing; no programming experience required

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course Description
This intensive graduate course provides hands-on training in corpus linguistics and learner language analysis. Students will gain practical experience with industry-standard tools for analyzing linguistic data, with special emphasis on learner corpora and their applications in language teaching and research.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Understand fundamental concepts in corpus linguistics
Apply corpus analysis tools to investigate linguistic phenomena
Analyze learner language using corpus methods
Evaluate corpus-based research critically
Design small-scale corpus studies
Interpret statistical results from corpus data

Day 2: Advanced Analysis

Day 4: Statistical Methods

title: Course Policies
text:
Attendance is mandatory for this intensive course
Missing more than one session may result in course failure
If you must miss a session due to illness or emergency, contact the instructor immediately
Make-up work may be assigned for excused absences







All assignments are due at 9:00 AM on the specified day
Late submissions will receive a 10% penalty per day
Extensions may be granted for documented emergencies





Submit all assignments via the course management system
Use the provided templates when available
File naming convention: LastName_Assignment#.ext
Acceptable formats: .docx, .pdf, .ipynb (for Python notebooks)








All work must be your own
Properly cite all sources
Plagiarism detection software will be used
Violations will result in course failure





Discussion with classmates is encouraged
However, all submitted work must be completed individually
Clearly indicate if you received help from others
Group work is only permitted when explicitly stated








Bring a laptop to every session
Ensure all required software is installed before Day 1
Have a backup plan (USB drive, cloud storage)
Test your setup before the course begins





Laptops should be used for course activities only
Silence mobile phones
No recording without permission
Be respectful during online activities

Online participation available if quarantined

This is an intensive course; take care of yourself

Don’t hesitate to reach out if you’re struggling








Original research using course methods
3,000-5,000 words
Must include corpus analysis component
Detailed guidelines in Final Project

Anonymous course evaluations will be distributed on Day 5
Your feedback helps improve the course
Evaluations do not affect your grade
Both numerical ratings and written comments are valuable







Course sessions may not be recorded without permission

Treat guest speakers with respect

Any research involving human subjects requires ethics approval
Corpus data must be used according to license agreements
Respect copyright and intellectual property





If you have questions about any policy, please don’t hesitate to ask. The goal is to create a productive and supportive learning environment for everyone.

text:

This course is conducted in English

title: Course Policies
text:

title: Course Policies
text:
Original research using course methods
3,000-5,000 words
Must include corpus analysis component

Proposal due: Day 5 (in class)
Final submission: 2 weeks after course ends
Feedback provided: Within 1 week of submission

title: Course Policies
text:
Anonymous course evaluations will be distributed on Day 5
Your feedback helps improve the course
Evaluations do not affect your grade
Both numerical ratings and written comments are valuable

title: Course Policies
text:
Course sessions may not be recorded without permission
Instructor may record sessions for absent students
Recordings are for personal use only





Treat guest speakers with respect
Prepare questions in advance
Guest speaker materials are confidential unless otherwise stated





Any research involving human subjects requires ethics approval
Corpus data must be used according to license agreements
Respect copyright and intellectual property

title: Course Sessions
text:
Day-by-Day Overview

Day 1: Introduction and Foundations
Build a solid foundation in corpus linguistics concepts and basic tools.


Morning Sessions - Course introduction and overview - What is corpus linguistics? - Types of corpora

Afternoon Sessions - Hands-on with AntConc - Basic corpus searches - Frequency analysis


Key Skills: AntConc basics, concordance reading, frequency lists



Day 2: Advanced Corpus Analysis
Explore sophisticated analysis techniques for deeper linguistic insights.


Morning Sessions - Collocation analysis - Statistical measures - Keyword analysis

Afternoon Sessions - Regular expressions - N-grams and clusters - Tagged corpus work


Key Skills: Collocation statistics, keyword extraction, pattern searching



Day 3: Learner Language Analysis
Focus on analyzing non-native speaker language and learner corpora.


Morning Sessions - Learner corpus design - Available resources - Research applications

Afternoon Sessions - Error annotation - Interlanguage features - L1 influence detection


Key Skills: Error analysis, contrastive analysis, developmental patterns



Day 4: Statistical Analysis
Apply statistical methods to validate corpus findings.


Morning Sessions - Descriptive statistics - Distribution analysis - Effect sizes

Afternoon Sessions - Hypothesis testing - Chi-square tests - Data visualization


Key Skills: JASP usage, statistical testing, creating visualizations



Day 5: Advanced Topics and Integration
Synthesize learning and explore cutting-edge applications.


Morning Sessions - Formulaic language - Multi-word units - Pedagogical applications

Afternoon Sessions - Project presentations - Peer feedback - Future resources


Key Skills: Project design, presentation skills, independent research

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text: JASP (Jeffreys’s Amazing Statistics Program) is a free, open-source statistics program with a user-friendly interface. It’s designed to be intuitive for users familiar with SPSS while incorporating modern statistical methods including Bayesian analyses.

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text: JASP (Jeffreys’s Amazing Statistics Program) is a free, open-source statistics program with a user-friendly interface. It’s designed to be intuitive for users familiar with SPSS while incorporating modern statistical methods including Bayesian analyses.

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Why JASP for This Course?

Free and open-source: No license fees
User-friendly: Drag-and-drop interface
Real-time results: See analyses update as you work
Publication-ready output: APA-formatted tables
Reproducible: Save complete analyses
Modern statistics: Includes effect sizes and Bayesian options

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
System Requirements

Minimum Requirements

Windows: Windows 7 or higher, 64-bit
macOS: macOS 10.12 (Sierra) or higher
Linux: Ubuntu 16.04 or higher
RAM: 4GB (8GB recommended)
Storage: 500MB free space

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Installation

Windows

Visit jasp-stats.org
Click “Download” → Windows
Run the installer (.exe file)
Follow installation wizard
Launch JASP from Start Menu



macOS

Visit jasp-stats.org
Click “Download” → macOS
Open the .dmg file
Drag JASP to Applications
First launch: Right-click → Open (security)



Linux

Visit jasp-stats.org
Download AppImage or use flatpak
Make AppImage executable
Run from terminal or file manager

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Getting Started

Interface Overview

Three Main Panels

Data View: Spreadsheet for data
Analysis Panel: Available analyses
Results Panel: Output and visualizations



Ribbon Menu

File operations
Edit functions
Common analyses shortcuts




Loading Data

Supported Formats

CSV files (recommended)
Excel files (.xlsx)
SPSS files (.sav)
Copy/paste from clipboard



Import Steps

File → Open → Computer
Browse to file location
Select file
Verify variable types

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Course-Specific Analyses

Day 4, Session 1: Descriptive Statistics

Frequency Analysis

Descriptives → Descriptive Statistics
Select variables
Choose statistics:

Mean, median, mode
Standard deviation
Range, min, max

Enable plots:

Distribution plots
Box plots




Example: Corpus Word Length
Variables: word_length
Statistics: mean, SD, histogram
Split by: text_type



Day 4, Session 2: Group Comparisons

Independent Samples T-Test

T-Tests → Independent Samples T-Test
Dependent Variable: frequency_score
Grouping Variable: learner_level
Additional Statistics:

Effect size (Cohen’s d)
Confidence intervals
Assumption checks




Chi-Square Test

Frequencies → Contingency Tables
Rows: error_type
Columns: proficiency_level
Statistics:

Chi-square test
Cramér’s V
Expected counts





Day 4, Session 3: Correlation and Regression

Correlation Analysis

Regression → Correlation Matrix
Select variables
Options:

Pearson’s r
Spearman’s rho
Confidence intervals




Linear Regression

Regression → Linear Regression
Dependent: accuracy_score
Predictors: study_hours, vocabulary_size
Statistics:

R-squared
Coefficients
Assumption checks

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Data Preparation Tips

Variable Types

Nominal: Categories (e.g., L1_language)
Ordinal: Ordered categories (e.g., proficiency_level)
Scale: Continuous (e.g., test_scores)



Data Cleaning

Check for missing values
Verify variable types
Look for outliers
Create new variables if needed

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Common Analyses for Linguistics

Comparing Groups

T-tests: Two groups
ANOVA: Multiple groups
Chi-square: Categorical data



Relationships

Correlation: Linear relationships
Regression: Prediction models
Logistic regression: Binary outcomes



Descriptive Summaries

Frequencies: Count data
Descriptives: Continuous data
Explore: Detailed examination

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Output and Reporting

Tables

Right-click → Copy
Paste into Word/Google Docs
APA format ready



Plots

Right-click → Save as
High resolution for publications
Customizable appearance



Complete Analysis

File → Export Results
HTML or PDF format
Includes all output

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Troubleshooting

Common Issues
JASP won’t open - Check system requirements - Update operating system - Try compatibility mode (Windows)
Data import fails - Check file encoding (UTF-8) - Remove special characters - Save as CSV and retry
Analysis grayed out - Check variable types - Ensure data is selected - Verify analysis requirements
Slow performance - Close other applications - Reduce data size for practice - Update JASP version

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Best Practices

Before Analysis

Understand your data

Variable types
Sample sizes
Missing values

Plan analyses

Research questions
Appropriate tests
Assumptions to check




During Analysis

Start simple

Descriptive statistics first
Build complexity gradually
Check assumptions

Document steps

Save JASP file (.jasp)
Note decisions made
Keep analysis log




After Analysis

Interpret carefully

Effect sizes matter
Consider practical significance
Report limitations

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Integration with Course

Workflow Example

Export data from AntConc
Format in Excel/Sheets
Import to JASP
Run analyses
Interpret for linguistics



Sample Datasets

learner_errors.csv: Error analysis data
corpus_frequencies.csv: Word frequency data
collocation_strength.csv: Collocation measures

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Additional Resources

JASP Resources

Official Tutorials
YouTube Channel
JASP Data Library



Statistical Guidance

Statistics for Linguistics with R
How to Do Linguistics with R



Course Materials

Session slides with JASP examples
Practice datasets
Step-by-step tutorials

title: JASP Statistical Software Guide
text:
Quick Reference

Key Shortcuts

Ctrl+O: Open file
Ctrl+S: Save analysis
Ctrl+C/V: Copy/paste data
F5: Refresh analyses



Analysis Decision Tree
Comparing groups?
├─ Yes
│  ├─ 2 groups → T-test
│  └─ 3+ groups → ANOVA
└─ No
   ├─ Relationship? → Correlation/Regression
   └─ Categories? → Chi-square

Remember: JASP makes statistics accessible. Don’t hesitate to explore!

title: Linguistic Data Analysis I
text:
This intensive 5-day graduate course introduces students to corpus linguistics and learner language analysis. Through hands-on activities and practical applications, you’ll learn to use computational tools to analyze linguistic data, with a special focus on learner corpora.






Quick Links




📋 Course Syllabus
📅 Schedule
💻 Sessions
📝 Assignments
🔧 Resources

title: Linguistic Data Analysis I
text:
This intensive 5-day graduate course introduces students to corpus linguistics and learner language analysis. Through hands-on activities and practical applications, you’ll learn to use computational tools to analyze linguistic data, with a special focus on learner corpora.






Quick Links




📋 Course Syllabus
📅 Schedule
💻 Sessions
📝 Assignments
🔧 Resources

title: Linguistic Data Analysis I
text:
Course Overview



What You’ll Learn

Corpus analysis techniques
Learner language analysis methods
Statistical approaches to linguistic data
Practical applications with real corpora
Research methodology in corpus linguistics




Key Tools

AntConc - Corpus analysis software
JASP - Statistical analysis
Python - Text processing (via Google Colab)
BYU Corpora - Online corpus interfaces
Excel/Google Sheets - Data management

title: Linguistic Data Analysis I
text:
Course Structure
The course is organized into 5 intensive days:








Day
Theme
Sessions




Day 1
Introduction & Corpus Basics
Introduction to course, corpus linguistics fundamentals, AntConc basics


Day 2
Advanced Corpus Analysis
Advanced AntConc features, collocation analysis, keyword analysis


Day 3
Learner Language Analysis
Learner corpora, error analysis, interlanguage features


Day 4
Statistical Analysis
Descriptive statistics, significance testing, data visualization


Day 5
Advanced Topics & Projects
Multi-word units, project presentations, future directions

title: Linguistic Data Analysis I
text:
Prerequisites






Before the Course




Technical Requirements

Computer with internet connection
4GB RAM minimum (8GB recommended)
2GB free storage space

Software to Install

AntConc (free)
JASP (free)
Text editor (e.g., VS Code, Notepad++)
Google account for Colab

Background Knowledge

Basic familiarity with Excel/Google Sheets
No programming experience required
Interest in language analysis
